Kelvin Sampson is a renowned American college basketball coach and former player, known for his extensive experience in coaching top-tier programs. Sampson has had a storied career, spanning over three decades, with multiple stints as a head coach and assistant coach at various institutions, including Oklahoma, Indiana, and Houston.

Early Life

Kelvin Sampson was born in the Lumbee Native American community of Deep Branch in Robeson County, North Carolina. During his prep days at Pembroke High School, Sampson excelled in both the classroom and the athletic arena, serving as captain of his high school basketball team for two years. His father, John W. "Ned" Sampson, was also his basketball coach and was one of the 500 Lumbee Native Americans who made national news by driving the Ku Klux Klan out of Maxton, North Carolina in the Battle of Hayes Pond.

Sampson's athletic prowess continued at Pembroke State University (now UNC Pembroke), where he played basketball and baseball. As a senior, he was team captain and earned four letters in basketball and three in baseball. He also earned Dean's List recognition throughout his collegiate career and received the Gregory Lowe Memorial Award as the school's outstanding physical education major.

Personal Life

Sampson is married to Karen Lowry, and they have two children, Lauren and Kellen. Lauren is the Men's Basketball Director of External Operations at the University of Houston, and Kellen is an assistant coach at the same institution.

College Coaching Career

Sampson began his coaching career at Michigan State, but he soon moved to Montana Tech, where he became an assistant coach. After serving as an interim coach for one season, Sampson guided the Orediggers to a 73-45 record in his final four seasons. During his tenure, Montana Tech won three consecutive 22-win seasons and claimed three Frontier Conference championships.

Sampson's success at Montana Tech caught the attention of Washington State, which hired him as an assistant coach. Two years later, he was named the head coach of the Washington State Cougars in 1988. Sampson led the team to the NIT in 1992, marking the first time Washington State had participated in postseason play since 1983. He was named Kodak District 14 Coach of the Year by the NABC in 1991 and 1992.

Oklahoma

In 1994, Sampson became the 11th head coach at the University of Oklahoma. He was named national coach of the year in 1995 by the Associated Press, United States Basketball Writers Association, and Basketball Weekly after guiding the Sooners to a 23-9 overall record and 15-0 home mark. It was the second-best overall record posted by a first-year coach in Big 8 history.

Indiana

On March 29, 2006, Sampson was named the head coach at Indiana University following the resignation of Mike Davis. Sampson was the second minority coach in the history of the Hoosier basketball program. Upon taking the reins of the Indiana Hoosiers, he noted, "I love my job at Oklahoma, and I would not leave OU for any job unless it was a job like Indiana."

NBA

After his resignation from Indiana, Sampson spent three years as an assistant coach for the Milwaukee Bucks and three years as an assistant for the Houston Rockets.

Houston Cougars

Following the expiration of the five-year show cause penalty, the Houston Cougars hired Sampson to coach the men's basketball team on April 2, 2014. Sampson was instrumental in Houston's push to raise funds to build a $25 million practice facility in 2016 and a $60 million renovation to Hofheinz Pavilion (renamed the Fertitta Center) in 2018. Sampson led Houston to the NIT in his second and third seasons. In 2018, Houston posted its first Top 25 finish and won its first NCAA tournament game since 1984. In 2019, the Cougars won a school-record 33 games, only the fourth 30-win season in school history. They also advanced to the Sweet Sixteen, their deepest run in the tournament since advancing all the way to the national championship game in 1983 and 1984.

NCAA Violations

Sampson played a role in the controversial recruitment of star player Eric Gordon, who signed with Indiana after reneging on an early verbal commitment to the University of Illinois. Sampson was criticized by fellow coaches for failing to communicate with then-Illinois coach Bruce Weber about the recruitment and hiring people close to Gordon to gain favor.

NBA Career

On March 8, 2008, Sampson was hired in an advisory role by the San Antonio Spurs.

International Basketball

Sampson coached the 2004 Under-21 USA national team to a gold medal in the Under-21 Tournament of the Americas in Halifax, Nova Scotia, after it posted a 5-0 record. He was an assistant coach under George Karl for the US national team in the 2002 FIBA World Championship. Sampson was also the head coach of the United States Junior National Team that participated in the Junior World Games in Athens, Greece, in the summer of 1995.
